conclusion: To determine when objects A and B are farthest apart, analyze their positions over time based on their velocity-time (v-t) graphs.
The distance traveled by an object is given by the area under its velocity-time graph.
For object A, the velocity increases linearly from 0 to t2.
For object B, the velocity first decreases from t = 0 to t = t1, reaching zero at t = t1, and then increases from t1 to t2.
From t = 0 to t = t2, object A moves with increasing velocity. The area under the line of object A from t = 0 to t = t2 represents the distance traveled by A.
The area forms a triangle with a base of t2 and a height of the final velocity (vmax). Distance traveled by A: 1/2 * t2 * vmax.
From t = 0 to t = t1, object B's velocity decreases, and it travels a certain distance backward. The area under the curve of object B from t = 0 to t = t1 represents the distance traveled.
From t = t1 to t = t2, object B's velocity increases. The area under the curve of object B from t = t1 to t = t2 represents the distance traveled forward.
The total displacement of object B needs to be calculated considering the backward and forward movements.
To find when A and B are farthest apart, consider the difference in their positions over time.
At t = t1, object B has reversed direction and is moving back. Object A continues moving forward.
To find the exact time tf when they are farthest apart, look at the point where the difference between the areas under the curves is maximized.
The time at which A and B are farthest apart is when the areas under their respective curves diverge the most.
From the diagram, this occurs at t = t2, where the curves intersect for the second time, indicating they are moving towards each other after being farthest apart.
The two objects, A and B, are farthest apart at time t2.
